body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I would like to pass an argument to a program, but "Windows PowerShell" thinks program arguments are syntax errors.

Note:
I actually didn't upgrade my powershell to the latest version because the link provided doesn't tell me how to do that. If you actually want me to upgrade tell me how and not to link to some release with no download-button or information on how to upgrade. I also don't know which version I am on.

I also didn't search existing issues because I don't know what to search for. And searching for "argument" yielded 23 pages and I am not going to sift trough 23 pages.

### Expected behavior

```console
PS C:\Users\Redacted> "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\ssh.exe" -V
OpenSSH_8.5p1, OpenSSL 1.1.1k  25 Mar 2021
```
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS C:\Users\Redacted> "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\ssh.exe" -V
At line:1 char:40
+ "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\ssh.exe" -V
+                                        ~~
Unexpected token '-V' in expression or statement.
    + CategoryInfo          : ParserError: (:) [], ParentContainsErrorRecordException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : UnexpectedToken
```
```


### Error details

```console
I tried it with ', " and without any ".
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.19041.1023
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.19041.1023
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

_No response_

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
If you wrap a path in quotes, PowerShell treats it as a string, not a command. To invoke the string as a command, prefix `&`:

```powershell
& "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\ssh.exe" -V
```
